{{POV|date=January 2011}} {{Cleanup|date=January 2011}} Following the [[Iranian presidential election, 2009|2009 Iranian presidential election]], protests against alleged [[electoral fraud]] and in support of opposition candidates [[Mir-Hossein Mousavi]] and [[Mehdi Karroubi]] occurred in [[Tehran]] and other major cities in Iran and around the world starting after the disputed presidential election on 12 June 2009<ref name="cnn">{{cite news | title = Iran election protests turn violent | publisher = CNN | date = June 13, 2009 | url = http://www.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/meast/06/13/iran.election/index.html | accessdate = June 13, 2009}}</ref> and continued even after the inauguration of [[Mahmoud Ahmedinejad]] as [[President of Iran]] on 5 August 2009. This is a timeline of the events which occurred during [[2009 Iranian election protests|those protests]].
==2009== ===June=== '''June 13â15'''
In what was became the worst civil unrest in Iran in over a decade, clashes broke out between police and groups protesting the election results from early Saturday morning onward. Protests were initially mostly peaceful but became increasingly violent.<ref name="cnn"/> Demonstrators chanted phrases such as "Down with the dictator", "Death to the dictator", and "Give us our votes back".<ref name=youth>{{cite news|first=Dudi|last=Cohen| date = June 14, 2009| accessdate = June 14, 2009|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3730786,00.html|title=Tehran youth: I'll never vote in Iran again}}</ref><ref name=free/> Mousavi urged for calm and asked that his supporters refrain from acts of violence.<ref name=free>{{cite news|publisher=BBC News|title=Ahmadinejad defiant on 'free' Iran poll |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8099115.stm|date=June 13, 2009|accessdate=June 13, 2009}}</ref>
[[File:Iran election (1).jpg|thumb|Protesters in Tehran, June 13, 2009]]
Anonymous sources said that the police stormed the headquarters of the [[Islamic Iran Participation Front]] and arrested a number of people.<ref name=abc>{{citenews|title=Election Battles Turn Into Street Fights in Iran|publisher=[[ABC News]]|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory?id=7830630|date=June 13, 2009|accessdate=June 13, 2009}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref><ref name="reformists1">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8099218.stm |title=Iran reformists held after street clashes |publisher=BBC News |date=2009-06-14}}</ref>
Two hundred people protested outside Iran's embassy in [[London]].<ref>{{cite news|language=[[French language|French]]|publisher=[[Yahoo!|Yahoo! France]]|title=Manifestation devant l'ambassade d'Iran Ã Londres|url=http://fr.news.yahoo.com/3/20090613/twl-iran-presidentielle-gb-manifestation-ba66223.html| accessdate = June 13, 2009| date = June 13, 2009}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> Protests led by Iranian-Americans were also held outside the Iranian representative office in [[New York City]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Milburn |first=Ty |url=http://www.ny1.com/content/top_stories/100727/iranian-new-yorkers-protest-ahmadinejad-s-re-election/Default.aspx |title=24 Hour Local News | Top Stories | Iranian New Yorkers Protest Ahmadinejad's Re-Election |publisher=NY1 |date= |accessdate=2009-06-15}}</ref>
[[File:Burning bus, Iranian presidential election 2009.jpg|left|thumb|Burning bus during the election protests in Tehran, June 13]]
On Sunday, protests grew considerably in scope and violence, leading [[Al Jazeera English]] to describe the situation as the "biggest unrest since the [[Iranian Revolution|1979 revolution]]". It also reported that protests seemed spontaneous without any formal organization.<ref name=al>{{cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2009/06/2009613172130303995.html.|title=Poll results prompt Iran protests|publisher=[[Al Jazeera English]]| accessdate = June 13, 2009| date = June 13, 2009}}</ref> Buses and trash cans were burned, and parked cars blocked streets and highways in Tehran and routes leading into the city. Protesters attacked shops, government offices, police stations, police vehicles, gas stations and banks.<ref name=bbc>{{cite news|title=Iran Election sparks clashes |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8098942.stm|date=2009-06-14|accessdate=2009-06-14|publisher=BBC News}}</ref> Barricades were installed around all government ministries, embassies (there were reports of shootings outside the Russian Embassy, which supported the election results), Mehrabad and [[Imam Khomeini International Airport]], where there were scenes of large clashes with riot police. Large protests, which escalated into riots, broke out at [[Tehran University]], [[Amirkabir University]], and [[Shahid Beheshti University]].<ref name=cnn>{{cite news|title=Ahmadinejad hails election as protests grow |url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/meast/06/13/iran.election/index.html#cnnSTCVideo|accessdate=2009-06-14|publisher=BBC News | date=June 13, 2009}}</ref> Other protests occurred in [[Ahwaz]], [[Shiraz]], [[Gorgan]], [[Tabriz]], [[Rasht]], [[Babol]], [[Mashhad]], [[Isfahan]], [[Zahedan]], [[Qazvin]], [[Sari]], [[Karaj]], [[Tabriz]], [[Shahsavar]], [[Orumieh]], [[Bandar Abbas]], [[Arak, Iran|Arak]], and [[Birjend]].<ref name=NCR6488>{{cite news|title=Popular uprising a stamp of rejection of sham election, display of Iranians' determination |url=http://ncr-iran.org/content/view/6488/1/|date=2009-06-14|accessdate=2009-06-14|publisher=NCR}}</ref> In Gorgan, protestors broke into a Basij base and killed several IRGC officials, causing mass purges and attacks in the city. Since riot police are largely limited to Tehran, the IRGC and the Basij were dispatched to quell protests in other cities.
Reporters from the Italian state-owned television broadcaster [[RAI]] stated that one of its interpreters was beaten with clubs by riot police and the officers then confiscated the cameraman's tapes.<ref name=abc/> Also several [[BBC]] cameramen were beaten and arrested by [[Army of the Guardians of the Islamic Revolution|IRGC]] officials and had their tapes confiscated.<ref name="bbc"/><ref name=bbcjamming>{{cite web|title=Stop the blocking now |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/theeditors/2009/06/stop_the_blocking_now.html|date=2009-06-14|accessdate=2009-06-14|publisher=BBC News}}</ref>

Solidarity protests took place in [[Montreal]] at [[Place des Arts]];<ref name="MalaysiaJune 15">{{cite news|title=Malaysia police fire tear gas on Iran election protest|url=http://www.montrealgazette.com/news/Hundreds+Iranian+Canadians+rally+Place+Arts/1698701/story.html}}</ref> in [[Kuala Lumpur]], [[Malaysia]], where police fired tear gas to break up a protest at the city's [[United Nations]] building;<ref name="Gazette Montreal">{{cite news|title=Hundreds of Iranian-Canadians rally at Place des Arts|url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jVhmpJUAuT57CXXYX-OUTc7k8E7Q}}</ref> in [[Chicago]]; and in [[Copenhagen]].<ref name="Ekstra Bladet">{{cite news|title=HÃ¥b for Irans unge|url=http://ekstrabladet.dk/nyheder/samfund/article1182480.ece}}</ref>
'''June 16'''
[[File:Tehran protests (15).jpg|thumb|upright|Protesters in Tehran, June 16]]
Thousands of people massed the streets of Tehran again.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/8103577.stm |title=Middle East | Iran opposition keeps up pressure |publisher=BBC News |date=2009-06-16 |accessdate=2009-06-20}}</ref><ref name="nyttuesday16">{{cite news|title=Opposition in Iran Rejects Call for Partial Recount |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2009/06/17/world/middleeast/17iran.html | work=The New York Times | first=Nazila | last=Fathi | date=June 17, 2009 | accessdate=March 28, 2010}}</ref> A British journalist reported seeing special police keeping Basijs and demonstrators separated.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/opinion/commentators/fisk/robert-fisk-fear-has-gone-in-a-land-that-has-tasted-freedom-1706912.html|title=Robert Fisk: Fear has gone in a land that has tasted freedom|date=2009-06-17|accessdate=2009-06-17|publisher=[[The Independent]] | location=London}}</ref> Over 120 Tehran University professors who had resigned in protest of violence against students joined the protests after security forces violently raided university dormitories.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://ncr-iran.org/content/view/6509/1/|title=Iran: 120 professors resign and join sit-in by students in Tehran University|date=2009-06-16|accessdate=2009-06-16|publisher=[[National Council of Resistance of Iran]]}}</ref>
[[File:Tehran protest.jpg|left|A protester holds a sign reading "Be patient! The morning is coming...", June 16|thumb]]
The [[Guardian Council]] announced that it was prepared to order a partial recount, and ruled out an annulment of the vote.<ref name=nyttuesday16/> The concession was rejected by the main opposition candidate, Mir-Hossein Mousavi, demanding that a new election be held.<ref name=nyttuesday16/>
'''June 17'''
The [[Iranian national football team]] played against South Korea's team in Seoul on Wednesday, with some members of the Iranian team wearing green armbands in support of Mousavi.<ref>{{cite news|title=Iranâs star footballers show support for Moussavi|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/1e2c6eee-5b3b-11de-be3f-00144feabdc0.html|publisher=Financial times|accessdate=June 17, 2009}}</ref>
Another demonstration was held in [[Tehran]] centering around the [[7 Tir Square]]. [[Crowd size estimation|Estimates of the number of participants]] ranged between 70,000 and 500,000.<ref name="BBCFreshRally">{{cite news|work=[[BBC News]] |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/8104466.stm|title=Fresh rally takes place in Tehran|date=2009-06-18}}</ref>
[[File:Tehran protests 2009-06-17 19-39.jpg|thumb|upright|A woman protester with tape covering her mouth, engaging in silent protest while holding a photo of a protester casualty, Tehran, June 17]]
'''June 18'''
Candle-bearing protesters massed in central Tehran on Thursday near [[Toopkhaneh|Toopkhaneh square]], following a call by Mousavi to commemorate those who were killed on Monday's protests.<ref name="BBCFreshRally" /> Varying reports placed the crowd size between "tens of thousands"<ref>{{cite news|work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-iran-protests19-2009jun19,0,4249713.story|title=Iran protests continue for fourth day |date=2009-06-18 | first1=Borzou | last1=Daragahi | first2=Ramin | last2=Mostaghim | first3=Kim | last3=Murphy | accessdate=May 25, 2010}}</ref> and "more than 100,000."<ref name="june18bbc">{{cite news|work=[[BBC]] |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8108115.stm|title=Masses mourn protesters in Iran |date=2009-06-18}}</ref> A second, simultaneous protest with several hundred participants took place near the UN headquarters, while a counter rally was held by hard line students protesting former President [[Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani]]'s role in the pro-Mousavi protests.<ref name="june18bbc" />
The Guardian Council invited the three major challengers to meet to discuss their grievances.<ref>{{cite news|work=[[New York Times]] |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2009/06/19/world/middleeast/19iran.html |title=Protesters Gather Again, as Iran Panel Offers Talks |date=2009-06-18 | first1=Nazila | last1=Fathi | first2=Michael | last2=Slackman | accessdate=March 28, 2010}}</ref>
'''June 19'''
Supreme Leader [[Ali Khamenei]] spoke about the previous protests during his scheduled television appearance.<ref name=mourn>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/8108115.stm Masses mourn protesters in Iran]. BBC News Online. June 18, 2009</ref> He argued that "media belonging to [[Zionists]], evil media," were trying to divide the state and Western powers were casting doubts on the election.<ref name="Khamenei speech">{{cite news|title=Ruling Cleric Warns Iranian Protesters|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2009/06/20/world/middleeast/20iran.html |date=June 19, 2009|publisher=New York Times|author=Nazila Fathi and Alan Cowell|accessdate=June 19, 2009}}</ref> He announced that he would not to be willing to give in to "illegal pressures" to change the results, and said that the opposition leaders would be "responsible for bloodshed and chaos" if they did not stop the demonstrations.<ref name="Khamenei speech"/><ref name=afp-19june>{{cite news|title=Amnesty says up to 10 dead in Iran protests|url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hmI8SkGap6fUGvyrbGIRk5oKCA9Q|date=June 19, 2009|publisher=AFP|accessdate=June 19, 2009}}</ref>
Hours after Khamenei's speech, defeated candidate Mehdi Karoubi called for election results to be cancelled.â<ref name="Karoubi cancellation">{{cite news|title=Iran's Karoubi calls for election cancellation|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/latestCrisis/idUSEVA961207|date=June 19, 2009|publisher=Reuters}}</ref>
Mousavi spokesman [[Mohsen Makhmalbaf]] said "Mousavi's headquarters was wrecked by plainclothes police officers" with many staffers arrested, and Mousavi himself ordered by the Revolutionary Guard to stay silent. Makhmalbaf said his job was "to urge people to take to the streets because Mousavi could not do so directly".<ref>{{cite news|title=I speak for Mousavi. And Iran|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2009/jun/19/iran-election-mousavi-ahmadinejad|date=June 19, 2009|author=Mohsen Makhmalbaf|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=June 19, 2009 | location=London}}</ref>
Both houses of the [[US Congress]] condemned violence against demonstrators by the Iranian government.<ref name=obama>Stephen Collinson, [http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5ilgdyjrMe9wWMPc6rjNjGoq3eCeA Obama urges Iran to stop 'violent and unjust actions'], AFP 20-06-2009</ref>
An underground newspaper entitled Ø®ÙØ§Ø¨Ø§Ù, or "The Street," also printed an issue dated June 19.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/babylonbeyond/2009/06/iran-street-newspaper-distributed-by-protesters.html|title=IRAN: 'Street' newspaper is being distributed by protesters|accessdate=2009-06-29 | work=Los Angeles Times | date=June 20, 2009}}</ref>
'''June 20'''
[[State media|State-run]] television reported that at least 10 were killed and 100 injured on Saturday, as thousands of protesters swept into the streets of [[Tehran]], in open defiance of warnings issued Friday by Iran's Supreme Leader and Security Council. State media said 457 people had been detained over Saturday's violence. {{Citation needed|date=June 2009}}. A young Iranian woman, identified as [[Neda Soltan]],<ref>{{cite news|language=[[french language|french]]|publisher=egoblog.net|title=Her name was Neda|url=http://egoblog.net/2009/06/21/her-name-was-neda/ | accessdate = June 21, 2009| date = June 21, 2009}}</ref> was shot by the [[Basij]] and died in front of cameras on Kargar Avenue in Tehran.<ref>{{cite news|language=[[english language|english]]|publisher=BreakForNews.com|title=Unidentified Woman Shot Dead in Karegar Ave - 20 June 2009|url=http://breakfornews.com/KarekarAveShooting090620.htm | accessdate = June 20, 2009| date = June 20, 2009}}</ref> Highly graphic amateur videos of the killing rapidly spread [[viral video|virally]] across the internet after being posted to [[Facebook]] and [[YouTube]].<ref>{{cite news|language=[[english language|english]]|publisher=[[Youtube]]|title=Basij shots to a young woman in Tehran's Saturday June 20th protests|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=185vPe_gROA&feature=channel_page | accessdate = June 20, 2009| date = June 20, 2009}}</ref> On 20 June â a day after Khamenei had warned of a brutal reaction if unrest continued â the Tehran ambulance service's internal radio system confirmed that at least 47 people had died, many from gunshot wounds. http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2009/dec/27/iran-tehran-ayotollah-khamenei-protests
On Saturday night, the Iranian state-run news agency [[IRINN]] said an attacker had been killed earlier in the day outside Tehran at the entrance to the mausoleum that holds the body of former Supreme Leader Ayatollah [[Ruhollah Khomeini]]. The agency said the man "carrying the bomb" was killed, and there were no other casualties. [[Press TV]] was reporting that the bomber was the sole fatality, and that three other people were wounded at the shrine to Khomeini.<ref name=chaos>[http://edition.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/meast/06/20/iran.election/index.html Chaos prevails as protesters, police clash in Iranian capital], CNN 21-06-2009</ref> These claims have not been confirmed.
In a statement posted on the website of his ''Kalemeh'' newspaper, Mousavi repeated his demand for the elections results to be annulled, and charged that the fraud could destroy the country's [[republicanism]].<ref name=police>[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2009/06/2009620184151643728.html Police crack down on Iran protests], Al Jazeera 21-06-2009</ref> An ally of Mousavi reported that the opposition leader had told his supporters that he was ready for [[martyrdom]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/latestCrisis/idUSHAF058781 |title=Iran's Mousavi says ready for martyrdom-witness |publisher=Reuters |date=2009-02-09 |accessdate=2009-06-20}}</ref> and had called for a general strike.<ref>{{cite news|title=Mussawi fordert Irans regime heraus|url=http://www.spiegel.de/politik/ausland/0,1518,631609,00.html|date=June 20, 2009|publisher=Der Spiegel|accessdate=June 20, 2009}}</ref> Speaker of the Parliament (Majlis) [[Ali Larijani]] declared that a significant number of people believed the official election results to be fraudulent,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.khabaronline.ir/news-11125.aspx|title=Ù Ø³Ø¦ÙÙØ§Ù Ø¨Ù Ø¯Ø±Ø®ÙØ§Ø³ØªâÚ©ÙÙØ¯Ú¯Ø§Ù ØªØ¬Ù Ø¹Ø§Øª Ø§Ø¬Ø§Ø²Ù Ø¨Ø¯ÙÙØ¯|publisher=Khabar online|accessdate=June 21, 2009}}</ref> arguing that their opinion should be respected.<ref>{{cite news|title=Larijani criticizes Guardian Council, IRIB|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=98645&sectionid=351020101|date=June 21, 2009|accessdate=June 21, 2009|publisher=Press TV}}</ref>
State television quoted a council spokesman as saying that the Guardian Council had expressed its readiness to "randomly" recount up to 10 per cent of the ballots.<ref name=police/>

'''June 21'''
Iranian Foreign Minister [[Manouchehr Mottaki]] rebuked Britain, France and Germany for raising questions about reports of voting irregularities. Mottaki charged France with taking "treacherous and unjust approaches," and accused Britain of flying intelligence agents into Iran before the election to interfere with the vote. The election, he insisted, was a "very transparent competition." British Foreign Secretary [[David Miliband]] categorically denied the charge against his country, adding: "This can only damage Iran's standing in the eyes of the world."<ref name=eerie>[http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090621/ap_on_re_mi_ea/ml_iran_election In Tehran, an eerie calm as death toll jumps to 19], Associated Press (reprinted in Yahoo! News 21-06-2009</ref>
An Iranian official at the [[Ministry of Culture and Islamic Guidance]] announced the expulsion of [[BBC]] Tehran correspondent Jon Leyne but said the BBC office in Tehran would remain open. The semi-official [[Fars News Agency]], which said Leyne must leave within 24 hours, explained that he was accused of "dispatching fabricated news and reports" and "ignoring neutrality in news," as well as "supporting rioters and trampling the Iranian nation's rights."<ref>Hashem Kalantari and Fredrik Dahl, [http://www.reuters.com/article/newsMaps/idUSTRE55K15S20090621 Iran expels BBC correspondent: official], Reuters 21-06-2009</ref> Furthermore, Iranian officials detained Iranian-born, Canadian citizen and [[Newsweek]] journalist [[Maziar Bahari]].<ref>[http://www.newsweek.com/id/203015 Newsweek Reporter Detained.] [[Newsweek]]. Retrieved 21 June 2009.</ref> Campaign group Reporters Without Borders says 23 local journalists and bloggers have been arrested over the past week.
While the streets have generally been quiet in Tehran, the daughter of Hashemi Rafsanjani and four other relatives have reportedly been jailed. Security forces have labeled protesters as "terrorists" and demonstrators condemned the harsh tactics of government-backed militias. Officials have reiterated that they are prepared to use force against protesters. Reuters reported that Iran Police Chief Ismail Ahmadi Moghaddam told opposition leader Mousavi that "bandits are acting in the shadow of the illegal atmosphere created by you."<ref>{{cite news|title=Iran calms, but daughter of top Iranian cleric reportedly arrested|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-iran-arrests22-2009jun22,0,2269803.story|accessdate=June 21, 2009 | work=Los Angeles Times | first1=Jeffrey | last1=Fleishman | first2=Ramin | last2=Mostaghim | date=June 22, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Iran clerics criticize leadership over poll unrest|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idUSTRE55F54520090621|accessdate=June 21, 2009 | work=Reuters | date=June 21, 2009}}</ref>
[[Press TV]], an Iranian English-language news channel funded by the Iranian Government, reported that the Guardian Council admitted that there were some irregularities in the election, specifically that in over 50 cities more votes were cast than there were eligible voters. The council's spokesman, Abbas-Ali Kadkhodaei, stated that, "Statistics provided by [[Mohsen Rezaee|Mohsen Rezaei]] in which he claims more than 100% of those eligible have cast their ballot in 170 cities are not accurate -- the incident has happened in only 50 cities." The council also reported that these regularities would affect approximately 3 million votes, but stated that, "it has yet to be determined whether the amount is decisive in the election results."<ref>[http://www.presstv.ir/detail/98711.htm?sectionid=351020101 Guardian Council: Over 100% voted in 50 cities]. [[Press TV]]. Retrieved 21 June 2009.</ref>
'''June 22'''
The Guardian Council, the body in charge of supervising and certifying the elections in Iran, declared the incumbent President Ahmadinejad winner after dismissing the vote challenges, according to a front page report on CNN.com. The report said that PressTV, a semi-state run television network in the nation announced the decision via a spokesperson for the group. They said that while they agreed that in up to 50 cities votes were higher than those eligible to vote, but that it was not enough to result in anything beyond further investigations. [http://www.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/meast/06/21/iran.election/index.html]
Speaking at a news conference on Monday, foreign ministry spokesman [[Hassan Qashqavi]] accused Western governments of explicitly backing violent protests aimed at undermining the stability of Iran's Islamic Republic. He said the West was acting in an "anti-democratic" manner, instead praising Iran's commitment to democracy and stressing once again that the results of the presidential election were unimpeachable. Iran has strongly criticised the US and UK governments in recent days, and Mr Qashqavi reserved special scorn for the [[BBC]] and for the [[Voice of America]] network, which he called "government channels". He spoke as Tehran remained tense but quiet amid heavy security aimed at preventing new protests against the result of Iran's presidential election. Mr [[Mousavi]] has told his supporters, who have taken to the streets in their tens of thousands for more than a week, to continue their protests but not to put their lives in danger.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8112176.stm|title=West 'seeks Iran disintegration'|date=2009-06-22|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=2009-06-29}}</ref>
[[The Guardian]]'s live blog reported that at approximately 1:30 pm, General [[Ali Fazli]], the newly appointed commander of the Revolutionary Guards in Tehran province, has been arrested for refusing to carry Khamenei's order to use force against demonstrators.<ref>[http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/blog/2009/jun/22/iran-ayatollah-ali-khamenei Iran in crisis: live]. [[The Guardian]]. Retrieved 22 June 2009.</ref>
At 4:30 pm Tehran time, Iran's ambassador to London was summoned to the Foreign Office and told that Khamenei's remarks were unacceptable. British Prime Minister [[Gordon Brown]] later condemned the "repression" and "brutality" used against the protesters. At approximately the same time the British Embassy in Tehran announced they were evacuating the families of embassy staff members and issued a [[travel advisory]] against visiting Iran. The Foreign Office noted that, "further violence is possible," but said it did not believe it was necessary for British nationals already in Iran to leave the country.<ref>[http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2009/jun/22/iran-embassy-staff-families-evacuated Britain evacuates families of embassy staff in Iran] [[The Guardian]] Published 22 June 2009 17.07 BST. Retrieved 22 June 2009.</ref>

Riot police fired tear gas to disperse the crowd.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8112812.stm|title= Police break up new Tehran rally|date=2009-06-22|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=2009-06-29}}</ref>
'''June 23'''
According to social networking sites such as [[Twitter]] and online newspapers such as [[The Huffington Post]], many [[Iran]]ians have avoided the streets in fear of combat with the [[Basij]].{{Citation needed|date=July 2009}} Unconfirmed reports of moderate sized gathering were later proven by photography and video.{{Citation needed|date=July 2009}}
[[Barack Obama|U.S. President Obama]] condemned the use of violence in [[Iran]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/31507917 |title=Obama ratchets up language on Iran violence|date=23 June 2009|work=[[msnbc.com]]|accessdate=26 November 2009}}</ref> and made a reference to [[Death of Neda Agha-Soltan|Neda]] who was shot to death during a rally in [[Tehran]] by an unknown [[Basij]] [[sniper]]. It was also reported by the Iranian-government funded news service [[Press TV]] that [[Mahmoud Ahmadinejad]] would be sworn in by the [[Parliament of Iran]] either in late July or early August.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=98830&sectionid=351020101 |title=Iran sets date for Ahmadinejad to take oath of office|date=23 June 2009|work=[[Press TV]]|accessdate=26 November 2009}}</ref>
Iranians continued to gather in groups of several hundred, while [[Basij]] militants used tear gas to disperse protesters.{{Citation needed|date=July 2009}} The Iranian government stated that it would expel British diplomats for "unconventional behavior."{{Citation needed|date=July 2009}}
The Guardian reported that at least four Iranian players from the national soccer team who wore green armbands during the [[2010 FIFA World Cup qualification - AFC Fourth Round|fourth round World Cup qualifying match]] in Seoul received "life bans".<ref name="guardianSoccer">{{Cite news| url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2009/jun/23/iran-football-protest-ban| title=Iran bans election protest footballers| first=Robert| last=Tait| date=June 23, 2009| accessdate=July 14, 2009 | work=The Guardian | location=London}}</ref> The New York Times later reported that FIFA had asked the players to remove the armbands at halftime because the governing body prohibits any expressions that can be interpreted as political. '''June 24'''
Former Iranian President [[Mohammad Khatami]] reportedly made a call for peaceful mass stand-ins in bazaars across Iran, with the aim of disrupting commerce while avoiding the violent police crackdowns which have accompanied the more overt protests and riots.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://narcosphere.narconews.com/thefield/bazaar-comrades|title=To the Bazaar, Comrades!|accessdate=2009-06-29}}</ref>
A caller into the [[CNN]] newsroom who is a female Iranian citizen claimed that in [[Baharestan]] Square, [[Basij]] forces shot bullets into the crowd.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=02qY9K2iOqA |title=Broadcast Yourself |publisher=YouTube |date=2009-06-24 |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref> She also claimed that students and old men alike were being beaten by these guards. '''June 25'''
Mirhossein Mousavi remained defiant, denouncing the election as an "evil conspiracy," and refusing to "withdraw [his protests] for even one moment."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://andrewsullivan.theatlantic.com/the_daily_dish/2009/06/mousavis-graceful-resistance.html|title=Mousavi's Graceful Resistance|date=2009-06-25|publisher=Andrew Sullivan - The Atlantic|accessdate=2009-06-29}}</ref>
Compared to the earlier violence, June 25 was the calmest day that Tehran had seen in nearly two weeks. A source for [[The Guardian (UK)|The Guardian]] reported that this was likely due, at least in part, to the national university entrance exams being conducted on that day, in which 1.5 million young Iranians participated.<ref name="guardian-iran-crisis">{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/blog/2009/jun/25/iran-crisis|title=Iran crisis: live|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=2009-06-29 | location=London | first=Daniel | last=Nasaw | date=June 25, 2009}}</ref>
Another opposition candidate, [[Mahdi Karroubi]], postponed a vigil of mourning for the victims scheduled for June 25, pushing the date back at least a week. According to Karroubi's website, the memorial service was delayed because the authorities had not granted the organizers permission to hold the rally.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2009/06/25/world/main5112528.shtml|title=Mousavi Faces Heat, But Vows Not To Crack|date=2009-06-25|publisher=CBS News|accessdate=2009-06-29}}</ref>
Despite the relative quiet, there were still a few incidents. A group of mourners attempted to visit the grave of Neda Agha Soltan, but were turned away by riot police. Those who refused the order to disperse or were seen carrying green signs were arrested.<ref name="guardian-iran-crisis" /> Clashes were also reported in and around Enghelab square, a site of previous violence. Protesters were said to have come from two sides and tried to drive the police from the square. Youths reportedly threw stones at blockades and set a bus on fire, and gunfire was reported in the area.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://andrewsullivan.theatlantic.com/the_daily_dish/2009/06/livetweeting-the-revolution-day-10.html|title=Live-Tweeting The Revolution: Week 2|date=2009-06-28|publisher=The Atlantic|accessdate=2009-06-29}}</ref>
The day also saw the releases of a number of prominent Iranians who had been arrested for their parts in the opposition. According to Human Rights Watch, sixty-six of the seventy Iranian professors arrested the previous night were released from jail. Also freed were Alireza Beheshti, editor-in-chief of the pro-Mousavi newspaper Kalameh, and a photographer from the citizen journalist organization [[Demotix]].<ref name="guardian-iran-crisis" />
'''June 26'''

Because the Shariati Street entrance of Ghoba Alley and the other end were both blocked by barriers, about 2000 mourners packed in the alley, under surveillance of sharpshooters and heavy police presence, especially those fully deployed along Shariati Street. A witness reported that police used tear gas to disperse the people at the northern end of the Ghoba Alley.
There are Facebook posters who claimed to have attended the Ghoba gathering who disputed that there was serious clashes, claiming that the exit towards the United Nations office (which is at the northern end of Ghoba Alley) was peaceful and free of tear gassing or clashes. This claim, along with those of serious clashes, cannot be verified.
All YouTube postings that shows Ghoba setting are peaceful so far, including one with the crowd surrounding [[Alireza Beheshti]], who spoke via a loudspeaker, and was watched by a police officer behind. Beheshti conveyed to the crowd a message delivered by Mousavi over the phone. On the same day, there are new YouTube postings of some street (allegedly on Shariati Street leading to Ghoba Alley) marches with "[[Marg bar diktator]]" (death to dictator) shouted in unison, and some with smoldering objects and gunshots dispersing rioters. But these were clearly not shot at the narrow alley of Ghoba, and not necessarily on Sunday the 28th. The safety in the surrounding of a historical mosque, coinciding with an important memorial date in the Islamic Republic seem to have given police forces and the protesters such an uneasy moment of truce and standstill. This matches the pattern throughout centuries of Islamic history in which religiously-sanctioned gatherings became moments of freedom of political expression, and in which political dissents became symbiotic with a community held together by common interpretation of faith, which secular authorities had difficulties in outlawing.<ref>{{cite web|author=28 juni 2009 |url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UcvfXKe1y30 |title=June 28 Iranians rally at Ghoba Mosque (also spelled Qoba) on Shariati Street, Tehran |publisher=YouTube |date=2009-06-28 |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref> This has led to some witnesses to urge the Muslims among the Greens to pray silently in large numbers at mosques during prayer hours, especially on Fridays, as a silent protest against the government's prohibition on any gathering.

Injuries were reported, among them an elderly woman who was allegedly beaten by police. Her beating reportedly enraged nearby protestors, who attacked the police in turn<ref>[http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/ap/top/all/6501464.html ]{{Dead link|date=March 2010}}</ref>
A Sunday June 28 YouTube posting shows a riot raging in a northern Tehran neighborhood (with the [[Alborz]] Mountain in the backdrop, which was on an unconfirmed date around sunset. And the video camera, viewing from a tall building, could record a uniformed armed policeman randomly shooting into the streets.<ref>{{cite web|author=28 juni 2009 |url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0EgJwm-IlNQ |title=28 June - Tehran - last News |publisher=YouTube |date= |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref>
However, by midnight Tehran time, CNN described the Ghoba protest as "silent", with peaceful end. The Iranian government-funded [[Press TV]] also described the event as "silent", consisting of "hundreds" of people that are admittedly "Mousavi supporters" commemorating the 1981 martyrdom of [[Mohammad Beheshti]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=99288&sectionid=351020101 |title=Mousavi supporters join Beheshti commemorators |publisher=Presstv.ir |date= |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref>
'''June 29'''
In Paris, thousands of demonstrators took to the streets in a show of solidarity with the Iranians.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.flickr.com/photos/sachaqs/sets/72157620539995973/ |title=#IranElection Paris rally - june 28, 2009 - a set on Flickr |publisher=Flickr.com |date=2009-06-28 |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref>
Meanwhile, Egyptian security forces shut down a scheduled solidarity march through the streets of Cairo, planned in honor of Neda Agha Soltan. Egyptian dissidents accused their government of hypocrisy, for having denounced the Iranian regime's repressive actions only days before banning the march.<ref>{{cite news|author=June 29, 2009 |  8:55 am |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/babylonbeyond/2009/06/egypt-marsh-showing-solidarity-with-iranian-martyr-banned.html |title=EGYPT: Police shut down Iran solidarity march | Babylon & Beyond | Los Angeles Times |publisher=Latimesblogs.latimes.com |date=2009-06-29 |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref>
On the floor of the Iranian Parliament, a physical confrontation broke out between MP Pezeshkian, who had urged the regime to show restraint, and hard-line MPs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://translate.google.com/translate?u=http%3A//www.baztabonline.com/Default%2Cfa-IR%2CBaztabOnline%2CContent%2CNewsDetail%2CKey%2C15345.aspx&hl=en&langpair=auto|en&tbb=1&ie=UTF-8 |title=Google Translate |publisher=Translate.google.com |date= |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref>
Signs of unrest continued today. Motorists in Tehran beeped their horns to signal their support for Mousavi, prompting basiji patrols to slash tires and break windshields. Meanwhile, in response to rumors of a human chain being formed, Tehran police massed at Valieasr Street to stop demonstrators from assembling.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/06/29/iran-uprising-live-bloggi_n_222087.html |title=Iran Uprising Live-Blogging (Monday June 29) |publisher=Huffingtonpost.com |date=2009-06-30 |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref> On this night, the rooftop chants of "Allahu akbar" continued.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/06/30/iran-uprising-live-bloggi_n_222970.html |title=Iran Uprising Live-Blogging (Tuesday June 30) |publisher=Huffingtonpost.com |date= |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref>
The Guardian Council reaffirmed Ahmadinejad's victory after recounting 10% of the votes. Upon the announcement of this news, protesters once again took to the streets of Tehran, and clashes were reported in the city. Although the police cleared the streets relatively quickly, citizens throughout the capital resumed the shouting of revolutionary slogans from the rooftops.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.nytimes.com/2009/06/30/world/middleeast/30iran.html | work=The New York Times | title=Iran Council Certifies Ahmadinejad Victory | first=Michael | last=Slackman | date=June 30, 2009 | accessdate=March 28, 2010}}</ref>
'''June 30'''
It is reported that dissidents in Tehran, in response to the closing of newspapers, have started writing anti-government graffiti on walls throughout the city.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://moriab.blogspot.com/ |title=Iran Watch Canada |publisher=Moriab.blogspot.com |date= |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref>
A crowd of over 2,000 people gathered at a courthouse in [[Uromieh]] seeking information about jailed relatives. No protest activity or violence was reported at this gathering.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/06/30/june-30-latest-updates-on-irans-post-election-turmoil/ | work=The New York Times | first=Rogene | last=Fisher | date=June 30, 2009 | accessdate=March 28, 2010 | title=June 30: Latest Updates on Iran's Post-Election Turmoil}}</ref>
Many expatriates from [[Muslim countries]] expressed that they wish to visit the [[Behesht-e Zahra]] Cemetery in peace, or at least as close to the site of [[Neda Agha-Soltan]]'s first burial site as possible on Saturday-Sunday, July 4â5, the 2-week anniversary of her death, since the martyred woman wasn't given a proper Muslim funeral.
On the date of Ghoba, although some expatriates expressed that they would like to attend the Mosque gathering to show faith to Allah, the Ahmadinejad regime arrested 9 British diplomats as soon as they caught wind that certain Iranian-born British diplomats might be attending. Now most of the British diplomats were released under international pressure. But this{{Which?|date=July 2009}} Iranian-born British diplomat is still under interrogation.
Recently, because Ahmadinejad has openly insulted the Prophet's two Sahaba,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2009/07/02/77608.html|title=Ahmadinejad unwelcome in Egypt: lawyer|publisher=[[Al Arabiya]] News Network|accessdate=August 23, 2009}}</ref> he has drawn much anger from the Ikhwan al-Muslimin in Egypt, and much contempt from even [[Hosni Mubarak]]. Mubarak pointed out, he or the King of Saudi Arabia would never insult the [[Shia]] faith in such a manner. {{Citation needed|date=July 2009}}

'''July 4'''
Thousands mourn Neda Agha-Soltan at Behesht Cemetery, Tehran. Her grave was strewn with rose petals, and adorned with the slogan "We Are Neda".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.demotix.com/news/mourning-dead-tehran |title=Mourning the dead in Tehran |publisher=Demotix.com |date=2009-06-30 |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref><ref>http://www.demotix.com/sites/default/files/imagecache/large_652x488_scaled/photos/99606.jpg</ref><ref>http://www.demotix.com/sites/default/files/imagecache/large_652x488_scaled/photos/99605.jpg</ref><ref>http://www.demotix.com/sites/default/files/imagecache/large_652x488_scaled/photos/99602.jpg</ref> New YouTube video surfaced on July 3 of the moment before Neda was shot. Video was filmed on roof top. Even though Khosravi Street was not directly filled with violence, it was certainly not far from the view of bike-riding Basijis. The shot that killed her was not the only shot heard in the video, though the last.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AIyLCOSDIlo |title=Broadcast Yourself |publisher=YouTube |date= |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref> It was apparent that the black-veiled woman (apparently Neda) accompanied by the blue-shirted old man (apparently Panahi), was shot by the bike-riding Basijis shooting at the "Marg bar diktator!" shouters, who were not close, but fully within view of the walking woman. This observation is in sharp contrast to the Iranian government's explanation that Neda's shooting was carefully set up by [[Arash Hejazi]]. If Neda's death was so carefully set up, the dozens of other violent deaths in Tehran in these few weeks can also be likewise explained, while the police and Basijis were the only people evidently armed with fire weapons, and were caught on films smashing private properties without provocation. It is also contrary to the account that the site of her shooting is entirely out of the range of rioting streets. What this video can not show, is whether there was any armed bike-riders going out of their way from the rioting street behind, to attack the woman at close range.
The Assembly of Teachers and Scientists at the [[Qom]] School for Shiite Clerics declared the 2009 election in which Ahmadinejad won "illegitimate".<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/05/world/middleeast/05iran.html | work=The New York Times | title=Clerical Leaders Defy Ayatollah on Iran Election | first1=Michael | last1=Slackman | first2=Nazila | last2=Fathi | date=July 5, 2009 | accessdate=May 25, 2010}}</ref>

[[File:A shot of the demonstration of 18-Tir.JPG|thumb|Demonstrations on the anniversary of 1999 student protests, July 09]] This date, being an anniversary of [[Iran student protests, July 1999|18 Tir Massacre]], had been predicted to be a day of massive protests in Tehran. The message asks supporters to attend peaceful and solemn ceremony at the [[Mosallah Mosque]] of Tehran, the largest mosque in the city,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skyscrapercity.com/showthread.php?t=704704 |title=[Tehran] Mosallah | Largest Mosque |publisher=SkyscraperCity |date= |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://iranfacts.blogspot.com/2007/05/iranian-experience-4.html |title=neo-resistance: Iranian Experience (4) |publisher=Iranfacts.blogspot.com |date=2007-05-14 |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref> located in the [[Abbas Abad]] district. Before the 6pm prayer, main activities took place at 4pm at the burial sites of the martyrs, namely the [[Behesht-e Zahra]] Cemeteries, which Mousavi and [[Mehdi Karrubi]] were set to attend. After the service at the mosque, the leaders paid visits to and show solidarity with some families who have lost their members in the violence. This message also ties into Mousavi's earlier message that "religious celebrations are opportunities for the display of the 'Green' movementâs creativity."
After arriving to Behesht-e Zahra cemetery, Mousavi was forced by police to go back to his car and leave the site. Basij units were dispatched to halt demonstrations and disperse the crowd. Police forces reportedly used tear-gas against the mourners. Some arrests have been reported by eyewitnesses.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rferl.org/content/Iranian_Police_Arrest_Mourners_In_Cemetery_Memorial/1788959.html|title=Iranian Police Arrest Mourners In Cemetery Memorial|date=2009-07-30|publisher=Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty}}</ref>
Opposition supporter Mehdi Karroubi attempted to give a speech at the cemetery, but was reported to have been forced to flee the site. Reports also say that several of his aides were beaten and harassed.<ref name="july29" />
Renowned film director [[Jafar Panahi]] and his wife and daughter were arrested at the cemetery.<ref>{{cite web|author=(AFP) – July 30, 2009 |url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hCiMXWvKwQvIo4JRRP28kB4zLWzQ |title=AFP: Iran 'arrests prominent film director' at cemetery |publisher=Google.com |date=2009-07-30 |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref>
[[Ali Reza Tavasoli]], a 12-year old, was clubbed to death by the Basij after he became separated from his father on the ground of Behesht-e Zahra on Mordad 8th.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3757738,00.html|title=Report: Iranian officers beat 12-year old to death|accessdate=6 August 2009}}</ref><ref name=theaustralian>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,26093533-2703,00.html|title=Ahmadinejad's Basiji run a regime of rape, murder to suppress critics|publisher=[[The Australian]]|accessdate=October 4, 2009 | first1=Martin | last1=Fletcher | date=September 19, 2009}}</ref> Someone allegedly captured the death on video. '''December 7'''
December 7 (16 of Azar on the [[Iranian calendar]]) is [[Student Day (Iran)|Student Day]] in Iran ({{lang-fa|Ø±ÙØ² Ø¯Ø§ÙØ´Ø¬Ù}}). It is the anniversary of the murders of three students from the [[University of Tehran]] on December 7, 1953 by Iranian police under the [[Pahlavi dynasty|Shah's]] rule.<ref>{{cite book|last=Yaghmaian|first=Behzad|title=Social change in Iran: an eyewitness account of dissent, defiance, and new movements for rights|publisher=SUNY Press|year=2002|page=240|isbn=978-0791452110}}</ref> People across Iran broke out in protests on December 7, 2009 in remembrance of the murder and protests on this day in 1953, as well as the [[Iran student protests, July 1999|student protests in July 1999]]. The protests in July 1999 were, at that time, the most widespread public protests to occur in Iran since the [[Iranian Revolution]].<ref>Ebadi, Shirin, ''Iran Awakening'', by Shirin Ebadi with Azadeh Moaveni, Random House New York, 2006, p.149</ref> However, the 2009 election protests have surpassed the 1999 protests to become the largest protests in Iran since the Iranian Revolution.
Thousands of university students in Iran turned a student rally into anti-government protests. Security forces and militiamen clashed with thousands of protesters shouting "death to the dictator" outside Tehran University. The night before the protests, rooftop cries of "Allahu akbar" or "God is great" and "death to the dictator" were heard from many parts of Tehran in support of the opposition. The rooftop chants â which were almost every night in the weeks following the election â had not been heard since the November protest.<ref>[http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20091207/ap_on_re_mi_ea/ml_iran_26 ]{{Dead link|date=March 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/meast/12/07/iran.protest.warnings/index.html?eref=edition |title=Iran police clash with protesters - CNN.com |publisher=Edition.cnn.com |date=2009-12-07 |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref> Protests were held at most universities across the country, with the largest at University of Tehran, Amirkabir University, Khajeh Nasir University, Kerman University, Sharif University in Tehran, Azad University, Azad University of Qazvin , and Mashhad University.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.payvand.com/news/09/dec/1069.html|title=Videos: Iran Students Stage Nationwide Protests |publisher=Payvand|accessdate=7 December 2009}}</ref> These would be the largest protests in Iran since November 4, 2009. [[Ayatollah Ali Khamenei]] blamed the United States and Britain for the protests<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.payvand.com/news/09/dec/1064.html|title=Iran's Supreme Leader Blames West for Student Protests |publisher=Payvand Iran News|accessdate=7 December 2009}}</ref> At a speech in [[Mashhad]], Former Iranian President Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani criticized the Iranian government's actions, quoting a verse from the Quran: "A secure society is a society that is pious and not subject to tyranny."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/meast/12/06/iran.protest.warnings/index.html?section=cnn_latest|title=Iran prepares for Students Day protests|publisher=CNN|accessdate=7 December 2009 | date=December 6, 2009}}</ref> According to reports, more than 200 people were arrested during the Students' Day protests and many were injured.<ref>{{cite news|author=Post |url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB126032215259182881.html |title=Iran Protest Continues, Under Siege - WSJ.com |publisher=Online.wsj.com |date=2009-12-09 |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref>

'''December 28'''
Iran declares martial law in [[Najafabad]]. Najafabad is the hometown of the opposition cleric Grand Ayatollah Hossein Ali Montazeri, who died the previous week. The decision to establish martial law came from the protests surrounding his death and funeral.<ref name=tvwashingtondec28>{{cite web|url=http://televisionwashington.com/floater_article1.aspx?lang=en&t=1&id=16788|title=Iran declares martial law in Najafabad|publisher=WashingtonTV}}</ref> This is the first time since 1978 revolution that martial law was established in Iran.<ref name=tvwashingtondec28 /> Additionally several leading opposition activists were arrested, including three of Mousaviâs top aides, two advisers to the reformist former president Mohammad Khatami, Nooshin Edabi, the sister of Nobel Peace Prize winner [[Shirin Ebadi]] (who's Peace Prize had been seized by Iranian authorities earlier in the year),<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8433464.stm|title=Sister of Nobel laureate Shirin Ebadi 'arrested in Iran'|publisher=BBC|accessdate=29 December 2009 | date=December 29, 2009}}</ref> and two other opposition activists, [[Ebrahim Yazdi]], who previously served as foreign minister of Iran, and the human rights campaigner [[Emadeddin Baghi]].
Seyed Ali Mousavi's body was confiscated from his family in an attempt by the government to prevent his funeral from becoming another anti-government demonstration. Iranian government security forces used tear gas to disperse the protesters that gathered outside the hospital where Seyed Ali Mousavi's body was.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/middle_east/article6969523.ece|title=Seven opposition leaders arrested as Mousavi nephew's body is seized|publisher=TimesOnline UK|accessdate=28 December 2009 | location=London | first=Martin | last=Fletcher | date=December 29, 2009 | accessdate=March 28, 2010}}</ref>
US President Barack Obama condemns the violent crackdown on the protesters, and Russia expresses concern at the events, urging restraint.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://en.rian.ru/russia/20091228/157405302.html|title=Russia voices concern over Tehran unrest |date=December 28, 2009|publisher=[[RIA Novosti]]}}</ref> Other Western countries, including the UK, France, and others condemned the violent crackdown on protesters.

==2010== ===January=== '''January 1 '''
During Friday Prayer services in the capital, Ayatollah [[Ahmad Jannati]], a fundamentalist cleric who leads the powerful Guardian Council, called protesters âflagrant examples of the corrupt on Earthâ and effectively urged that they be executed as âin the early days of the revolution.â<ref name="nytimes.com"/>
In a public statement released through internet and to media outlets, Mir Hossein Mousavi declares he is ready to be [[martyr]]ed for his cause as hardliner clerics in the regime even call for his and other opposition leaders (including Mehdi Karoubi) execution. Mousavi said on his website: âI am not afraid to die for people's demands. Iran is in serious crisis. Harsh remarks will create internal uprising.â As a way out of the crisis, Mousavi has put forward a five point plan to the Government for political and social reforms. But he says Iran's leaders must accept responsibility for the crisis and stop its crackdown on dissent. He's called for the release of all political prisoners, more transparent election laws, and a recognition of the right to protest and a free press.<ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/am/content/2009/s2784149.htm Mousavi prepared to die for his cause]</ref>
Huge protest took place in Mashhad University. More than 200 students of the Mashhad Open University in north-eastern Iran had been arrested, opposition websites reported. According to the reports, 210 students supporting the Green Movement had been arrested in the last 48 hours. The reports added that some of the students were also attacked by radical pro-government supporters and that two female students with stab wounds were in a critical condition. Several students gathered in front of a police station in Mashhad, demanding the immediate release of their fellow students and were further planning a sit-in-strike on Saturday at their university.<ref>[http://www.earthtimes.org/articles/show/301734,report-over-200-students-arrested-in-north-eastern-iran.html Report: Over 200 students arrested in north-eastern Iran]</ref>

;June 12 Several scattered protests broke out throughout the country on the anniversary of the election, despite warnings from the government and security forces against protesting. However, there were no major widespread protests. Minor sporadic protest took place at Tehran's Azadi Square and at some universities throughout Iran.<ref>http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/06/13/iran-protest-anniversary_n_610394.html</ref><ref>http://www.insideofiran.com/en/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=3569:muted-protests-mark-iran-vote-anniversary&catid=42:important-news&Itemid=57</ref> Mir-Hossein Mousavi and Mehdi Karroubi both cancelled planned protests fearing violence.<ref>http://www.insideofiran.com/en/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=3535:warning-against-iran-vote-anniversary-protests&catid=42:important-news&Itemid=57</ref>
===September=== ;September 2 Pro-government mobs attacked the home of Mahdi Karroubi.<ref>http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/38987040/ns/world_news-mideastn_africa/</ref>
;September 11 Hamid Mohseni, the head of Mir Hossein Mousavi's office was arrested by Iranian security forces.<ref name="Securityforces2010">{{cite news| url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2010/09/17/security-forces-raid-office-irans-main-opposition-leader/ | work=Fox News | title=Security forces raid office of Iran's main opposition leader | date=September 17, 2010}}</ref>
;September 12 Hossein Alizadeh, the [[Charge d'affaires]] and number 2 diplomat at the Iranian Embassy in [[Helsinki]], [[Finland]], resigned in protest of the Iranian government's hardline stance.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://articles.latimes.com/2010/sep/12/world/la-fg-iran-diplomat-20100912 | work=Los Angeles Times | title=Iran diplomat in Finland resigns to protest hard-liners at home | date=September 12, 2010 | first=Alexandra | last=Sandels}}</ref>
;September 17 Iranian security forces raided the office of Mir Hossein Mousavi.<ref name="Securityforces2010" />
===December=== ;December 7 Students protest at [[Amirkabir University of Technology]] in Tehran. They are attacked by the basij and the protest is suppressed.<ref>[http://vodpod.com/watch/5071210-7-december-2010-iran-opposition-protests-amirkabir-university-basij-attacking-students VodPod Video: Iran Opposition Protests Amerkabir University Basij Attacking Students, 07.12.10]</ref>
== 2011 == {{main|2011 Iranian protests}}
===February=== ;February 14 Iran's opposition has called for renewed street protests next week on the back of the wave of demonstrations that have swept across the Middle East. Mir Hossein Mousavi and Mehdi Karroubi, the leaders of the green movement in Iran, have issued a call for what they have described as "a solidarity move to support the protests in two Muslim countries of Egypt and Tunisia" on Monday.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/08/iran-opposition-green-movement-tehran-protest | location=London | work=The Guardian | title=Iran's opposition green movement calls for renewed street protests | date=February 8, 2011}}</ref>
